title-group.article-title: Importance of sarcomere length when determining muscle physiological cross-sectional area: A spine example

contrib-group.aff: Department of Human Health and Nutritional Sciences, University of Guelph, Canada

abstract.p: Muscle physiological cross-sectional area predicts the maximum capability of a muscle to generate isometric force. Biomechanical models often use estimates of individual muscle physiological cross-sectional area to partition internal forces among different muscles and predict joint forces and stability. In the spine literature, these physiological cross-sectional area values are generally obtained from imaging or cadaveric studies that have not accounted for a potential lengthened or shortened (and thus thinned or thickened, respectively) state of the muscles in question. Sarcomere length measurements can be used to normalize muscle lengths and correct for these length discrepancies. This article was designed to demonstrate potential effects of not accounting for instantaneous sarcomere length when calculating the physiological cross-sectional area of muscles of the spine region. Because some muscles of the spine region appear to be shortened and others lengthened in the neutral spine posture, both over- and under-estimations of physiological cross-sectional area are possible. Specifically, it is shown that the muscle physiological cross-sectional area could be over-estimated or under-estimated by as much as +36% (multifidus) and −21% (rectus abdominis), respectively. This differential error effect poses difficulties in accurately estimating individual muscle forces and subsequent spine forces and stability that result from biomechanical models incorporating physiological cross-sectional area data obtained in the absence of sarcomere length measurements. Future work is needed to measure the dynamic range of sarcomere lengths of all spinal muscles to ensure correct inputs to biomechanical models.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Musculoskeletal models designed to predict joint forces and stability require accurate estimates of muscle physiological cross-sectional area (PCSA) to partition internal forces across an array of muscles and passive tissues. These types of models are continually being developed and refined1–7 and represent a significant effort in the biomechanics and spine communities to predict potentially injurious scenarios and reduce the likelihood of spine injury. PCSA represents the number of force-generating sarcomeres arranged in parallel through a muscle, and defines the maximum isometric force-generating capability of a muscle.8 It can be calculated by

Optimal muscle length is obtained by normalizing to the sarcomere length at which maximum isometric force can be generated (optimal sarcomere length; 2.70 µm9). It is generally accepted that the most accurate method for quantifying muscle PCSA is to perform detailed dissections and measurements on fixed muscle tissue. This enables precise measurements of muscle mass, pennation angle, muscle fibre length and sarcomere length; thereby enabling highly accurate estimation of the dissected muscle’s force generating capability.10,11 However, a limitation of these measurements is the general older-age of the cadaveric donors examined. Thus, those interested in estimating muscle force production via biomechanical models often advocate performing measurements of muscle PCSA on living humans via imaging modalities. Indeed, excellent highly detailed imaging studies have been performed to estimate PCSA of the spine and abdominal wall muscles (for example Marras et al.4 and McGill et al.12). The best of these studies take into account obliquities between scan and muscle cross-sectional planes in an attempt to measure PCSA rather than an anatomical cross-sectional area. However, the major limitation of imaging-based modalities is the inability to measure the length of sarcomeres, which are the fundamental unit governing muscle force generation.

It is well established that the instantaneous length of a sarcomere greatly influences its ability to produce active force, based on the overlap between actin and myosin filaments.13 Further, muscle fibres display an isovolumetric behaviour, meaning that as they lengthen or shorten they thin or thicken, respectively, to maintain a relatively constant volume. Thus, imaging a muscle fibre in a shortened or lengthened position will over- or under-estimate its cross-sectional area, respectively. Gross muscle tissue, however, containing muscle fibres and their extracellular matrix, appear to demonstrate a Poisson’s ratio greater than 0.5 when stretched, indicating a loss of volume.14 This indicates that a stretched muscle will display extra thinning, and if this holds for shortening, the muscle would display a reduced thickening. Thus, imaging a muscle in a lengthened position would further under-estimate its PCSA. The importance of normalizing muscle fibre length to sarcomere length has been indicated in the past;8,10,15,16 however, the impact has not been demonstrated for muscles imaged and routinely used for biomechanical modelling.

In general, imaging studies designed to measure muscle PCSA in the spine region have not been able to account for the relative shortened or lengthened state of the imaged muscles and have, therefore, assumed that the muscles are at optimal length in the imaged position. In addition, some cadaveric studies reporting PCSA values for spine muscles have made this assumption as well (for example, Bogduk et al.17). Recent evidence has demonstrated that many of these muscles, however, are not at optimal length in these positions.18,19 Thus, the purpose of this article is to demonstrate the effect that this assumption has on estimates of PCSA and implications of this for biomechanical models.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Two separate analyses were conducted. The first was based on PCSA data for the multifidus muscle from a computed tomography (CT) study12 and cadaver study;17 neither of which were able to use sarcomere length to normalize muscle lengths for PCSA calculations. PCSA values from these articles are routinely incorporated into current biomechanical models of the spine (for example, van Dieen,2 Shirazi-Adl et al.,5 Christophy et al.,7 Brown and Potvin,20 and Hansen et al.21). The second analysis is based on PCSA data for the abdominal wall muscles (rectus abdominis (RA), external oblique (EO), internal oblique (IO), transverse abdominis (TrA)) from a cadaver study;18 this study used sarcomere length normalization, but affects will be tested as if this had not been performed.

sec.title: Analysis one: multifidus
sec.p: Both McGill et al.12 and Bogduk et al.17 performed detailed high-quality examinations of the spinal musculature; McGill et al. via CT scans and Bogduk et al. via cadaveric dissection. However, neither study was able to account for the length of sarcomeres within their measured muscles when estimating PCSA.

Therefore, if muscle CSA is measured at a non-optimal length (CSA’), the true PCSA can be estimated based on an estimated Poisson’s ratio for muscle and knowledge of the ratio between the measured muscle length and optimal length (measured sarcomere length and optimal sarcomere length).

Ward et al.19 measured in-vivo sarcomere lengths of the multifidus muscle from surgical biopsies and found them to be approximately 1.98 µm in the prone spine position, and also measured sarcomere lengths from cadavers fixed in a post-mortem neutral spine position and found them to be 2.28 µm. Both of these values suggest multifidus is quite short in the neutral spine posture. Therefore, the muscle would have likely been shortened and thickened in the posture measured in the McGill et al.12 and Bogduk et al.17 studies, thus overestimating PCSA. Equation (5) was used to estimate what the true PCSA would have been assuming that measures in these studies were taken when the multifidus was actually shortened to sarcomere lengths reported by Ward et al.19

sec.title: Analysis one: multifidus
sec.p: Based on a Poisson’s ratio for muscle of 0.5 (iso-volumetric), multifidus PCSA values reported by McGill et al.12 and Bogduk et al.17 would have been over-estimated by 36% assuming a prone-posture in-vivo sarcomere length of 1.98 µm19 or 19% assuming a sarcomere length of 2.28 µm (from prone cadaveric measurements).19 Smith et al.14 found that muscle tissue (muscle fibres combined with extra-cellular matrix) actually displays a Poisson’s ratio of approximately 0.74. Based on this ratio, multifidus PCSA overestimations by McGill et al.12 and Bogduk et al.17 are reduced to 11% and 5% assuming in-vivo sarcomere lengths of 1.98 µm and 2.28 µm, respectively.

sec.title: Analysis two: abdominal wall muscles
sec.p: For cadaveric measurements of the abdominal wall muscles,18 if sarcomere lengths had not been measured (and instead been assumed to be at optimal length), PCSA would have been over-estimated in the IO (5%) and TrA (6%) (over-estimated because actual measured sarcomere lengths were slightly below optimal) and under-estimated in the EO (17%) and RA (21%) (under-estimated because actual measured sarcomere lengths were well above optimal). Figure 1 displays a comparison between the true muscle PCSA and normalized fascicle lengths reported by Brown et al.,18 and the errors that would have been made had optimal sarcomere length been assumed.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study has demonstrated a substantial potential error in estimating PCSA of muscles of the spine region when sarcomere lengths are not accounted for. Highly sophisticated biomechanical models of the spine use estimates of muscle PCSA to predict forces applied to the spine and assess performance and injury potential.1–7 Recent work has reported sarcomere lengths for some spine muscles to be quite short (multifidus)19 or long (external and internal oblique),18 relative to optimal, in a neutral spine posture. This makes these muscles vulnerable to under- or over-estimations in fibre length and subsequently PCSA, in the absence of sarcomere length measurements. Future work is needed to assess the dynamic range of sarcomere lengths in other spine muscles (longissimus, iliocostalis, latissimus dorsi, psoas major, quadratus lumborum).

Electromyography (EMG)-driven biomechanical models of the spine have often used what has been termed a ‘gain’ factor that can be considered an attempt to account for potential discrepancies in overall muscle PCSA (i.e. force and moment generating capability) and actual inter-individual differences in PCSA.20,22–24 This gain estimation would theoretically account for overall under- or over-estimations in PCSA. However, in the case of the spine region muscles presented here, in particular the abdominal wall muscles, where muscle PCSAs have been calculated when some muscles are shortened and others lengthened, this gain factor will not adequately account for inter-muscle variation in PCSA error. This is an important limitation when the goal of the model is to partition individual muscle forces, force generating capabilities or spinal forces and stability.

In the post-mortem neutral spine posture Brown et al.18 reported RA and EO to act well beyond optimal sarcomere length (3.29 µm and 3.18 µm, respectively) whereas IO and TrA to act just below optimal sarcomere length (2.61 µm and 2.58 µm, respectively). As demonstrated here, calculating PCSAs of these muscles in the absence of these sarcomere lengths would have resulted in differential errors among the four muscles, overestimating IO (5%) and TrA (6%) force-generating capability and greatly underestimating the capabilities of RA (21%) and EO (17%). As spine stability, compression and shear force predictions are all highly sensitive to the orientation and magnitude of muscle forces, differential errors in PCSA could greatly compromise the validity of these outputs from biomechanical models. These differential effects can also impact ultrasound studies of abdominal wall muscles that use muscle thickness to allude to force-generating capabilities and general relative muscle function and health.

Mean multifidus sarcomere lengths have been measured at 1.98 µm in a prone neutral spine position,19 which is well below optimal length for human muscle (2.70 µm9). This led to predicted over-estimations of PCSA between 11% and 36%, depending upon the assumed Poisson’s ratio of muscle tissue. Other data have suggested that the bulk of the erector spinae (longissimus and iliocostalis) is also in a shortened state in the neutral spine posture,25 which would make reported estimates of their PCSA in imaging studies likely over-estimated. Future work is needed to test this hypothesis.

Our findings should be interpreted by considering that spine posture was not directly quantified in any of the reported studies; thus we have assumed that in the prone position the spine was in a similar neutral posture, and thus muscles at similar lengths, in all cases. Further, muscle length changes were predicted by a biomechanical model and may not occur in-vivo exactly as predicted. Despite these limitations, our findings have clearly highlighted the importance of considering sarcomere length in the determination of muscle PCSA.

This article has demonstrated potential errors in the calculation of muscle PCSA from imaging and/or cadaveric analyses in the absence of accurate sarcomere length measurements. A specific focus has been paid to muscles that affect the lumbar spine, as this region is often subject to biomechanical modelling analyses that use muscle force predictions to estimate spine stability and forces. Actual sarcomere length measurements indicate that errors can occur, ranging from underestimations of 21% to overestimations of 36% for individual muscle PCSA.
